newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia launches A$7 million anti-smoking plan.
newsitem.headline: Australia launches A$7 million anti-smoking plan.

text.p: The Australian government on Thursday launched a national anti-smoking campaign worth A$7 million over the next two financial years.

"This campaign -- which includes television commercials, print advertisements and practical support for smokers wanting to quit -- delivers the message that every cigarette you have does you damage," Health Minister Michael Wooldridge said in a statement.
"The advertising uses graphic images which confront and challenge smokers," Wooldridge said, adding that many smokers would be shocked and disturbed by them.
The campaign would be aimed at the 25 percent of people in Australia who still smoke, with around 18,000 Australians dying each year from smoking-related diseases, he said.
"Treatment and care of patients with these diseases, and associated expense, cost the Australian community an estimated A$12.7 billion each year," he said.
It would be the largest amount the national government had ever allocated to an anti-tobacco campaign, with additional funding provided by the states.
Australia's cigarette industry is dominated by Rothmans Holdings Ltd, W.D. & H.O. Wills Holdings Ltd and Philip Morris Australia.
Willis is majority-owned by B.A.T Industries Plc.
